Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Evaluating the Influences of Aerosols on Low-level Cloud-precipitation Properties over Land and Ocean using Ground-based Observations and WRF Simulations
Award.AbstractNarration:
Aerosol generation resulting from natural and anthropogenic activities is expected to have considerable, far-reaching effects on cloud development and the hydrologic cycle. Though the aerosol direct effect can simply be thought of as a reduction of incoming solar radiation reaching the Earth's surface, the aerosol indirect effect (AIE) involves a complex set of aerosol-cloud-precipitation interactions. These indirect effects include the alteration of cloud microphysical properties such as cloud lifetime, droplet size distribution, liquid water content and path, optical depth, and albedo. Precipitation processes will certainly be affected in numerous and at times, detrimental ways. Hence, there is a major impact to society as a whole due to a heavy dependence on the distribution of available water over a given region for public consumption, agriculture, and industrial purposes.

Intellectual Merit:
This research adopts a synergistic approach that uses the long-term ground-based observations and retrievals from the Southern Great Plains of the United States and Eastern North Atlantic Ocean regions to investigate the seasonal and diurnal variations of aerosol and clouds under the continental and maritime conditions, as well as compare their similarities and differences. Air parcel trajectory modeling will be conducted to identify the sources of air masses for the selected cases to investigate the AIEs over these two regions with additional WRF simulations. This study is important because it will aid to improve aerosol and cloud parameterizations as well as provide an in-depth understanding of aerosol-cloud-precipitation interactions in typical maritime and continental conditions. The following three scientific questions (SQs) will be investigated.
SQ1: What are the similarities and differences of aerosol-cloud properties, as well as their interactions over ocean and land?
SQ2: What are the indirect effects of aerosols on cloud microphysical properties?
SQ3: How does wind shear enhance turbulent mixing and stimulate drizzle formation?

Broader Impacts:
This research will benefit society by helping to provide better support for the modeling of aerosol-cloud-precipitation interactions which will aid in researching the long-term distribution of available water by clouds and precipitation processes. The far-reaching goal of this project is to further reduce uncertainties in the climate modeling community by providing better constraints for seasonal and regional aerosol and cloud properties. Moreover, there will be plenty of opportunities to introduce aerosol-cloud interactions as "real world" examples in undergraduate and graduate geoscience courses where the students can not only investigate these examples as interdisciplinary class projects, but also improve upon current research techniques and develop their own theses and dissertation areas of focus.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Aerosols generated from natural and anthropogenic activities have observable yet uncertain effects on clouds and precipitation.  This can negatively impact society because of the complex influences on the distribution of water availability for the public, agriculture, and industry. This collaborative study used a synergistic approach to (a) investigate the climatological variations of aerosol and clouds in continental and maritime settings and (b) quantify how different types of aerosols can influence precipitation development in these regions. A long-term dataset using ground-based observations from the United States Department of Energy (DOE) Atmospheric Radiation and Measurement (ARM) facilities located in the Southern Great Plains (SGP) and Eastern North Atlantic Ocean (ENA) regions was primarily used in this research effort along with ancillary ground, aircraft, and space-based measurements.  Once an aerosol climatology was quantified, a Weather Research and Forecasting (WRF) model was used to simulate aerosol impacts on cloud and precipitation development for selected clean (low aerosol) and polluted (high aerosol) conditions. This study added to the improvement of the understanding of aerosol-cloud-precipitation interactions in typical maritime and continental conditions by addressing the following three scientific questions (SQs):

SQ1:  What are the similarities and differences of aerosol-cloud properties, as well as their interactions over ocean and land? 

SQ2: What are the indirect effects of aerosols on cloud microphysical properties?

SQ3:  How does wind shear enhance turbulent mixing and stimulate drizzle formation? 

In terms of a broader impact, this study produced opportunities to not only foster more collaborations within the atmospheric science community, but also provided opportunities for undergraduate and graduate research. In fact, Dr. Logan devoted a large part of his research effort for six semesters to working with undergraduate students who were able to become co-authors on a recently published journal article (see publication list). In addition, his introductory meteorology class sections (ATMO 201) and supervised research sections (ATMO 291/491) had real-world examples to use as class projects. Moreover, research students were able to identify observational evidence of biomass burning smoke aerosols on severe weather and lightning and presented their findings at national conferences throughout the three year funding period of this grant.

A list of publications and conference proceedings resulting from this study are as follows:

  • Logan, T., Dong, X., and Xi, B. (2018). Aerosol properties and their impacts on surface CCN at the ARM Southern Great Plains site during the 2011 Midlatitude Continental Convective Clouds Experiment.  Advances in Atmospheric Sciences. 35 (2).
  • Zhang, Y., J. Fan, T. Logan, Z. Li, and C. R. Homeyer (2019), Wildfire impact on environmental thermodynamics and severe convective storms, Geophys. Res. Lett., 46. https://doi.org/10.1029/2019GL084534.
  • Zheng, X., B. Xi, X. Dong, T. Logan, Y. Wang, and P. Wu (2020), Investigation of Aerosol-Cloud Interactions under Different Absorptive Aerosol Regimes using ARM SGP Ground-Based Measurements, Atmos. Chem. Phys., https://doi.org/10.5194/acp-2019-478.
  • Logan, T., X. Dong, B. Xi, X. Zheng, Y. Wang, P. Wu, *E. Marlow, and *J. W. Maddux (2020), Quantifying long-term seasonal and regional impacts of North American fire activity on continental boundary layer aerosols and cloud condensation nuclei, Journal of Earth and Space Science, doi:10.1029/2020EA001113. *Denotes Dr. Logan?s undergraduate research students.
  • Wang, Y., Zheng, X., Dong, X., Xi, B., Wu, P., Logan, T., and Yung, Y. L. (2020), Impacts of Long-range Transport of Aerosols on Marine Boundary Layer Clouds in the Eastern North Atlantic, Atmos. Chem. Phys., https://doi.org/10.5194/acp-2020-623.
  • Pan, B., Wang, Y., Logan, T., Hsieh, J.-S., Jiang, J. H., Li, Y., and Zhang, R. (2020). Determinant role of aerosols from industrial sources in Hurricane Harvey's catastrophe. Geophysical Research Letters, 47, e2020GL090014. https://doi.org/10.1029/2020GL090014.
  • Logan, T. (2020), An analysis of the performance of the Houston Lightning Mapping Array during a period of intense convection over the Houston Metropolitan Area during Hurricane Harvey, accepted to Journal of Geophysical Research Atmospheres.
  • *Trujillo, J., *Truesdale, S., and Logan, T. (2018), Synoptic Analysis of Aerosols from Biomass Burning and Their Impacts on Severe Hail Events in the Contiguous United States, Poster, 98th Annual American Meteorological Society Meeting Student Conference, January 10, Austin, TX.
  • Logan, T., X. Zheng, B. Xi, and X. Dong (2019), Seasonal Influences of Aerosol Type on Low-Level Cloud Microphysical Properties under Different Airmasses at the ARM-SGP site, Poster, 99th Annual American Meteorological Society Meeting, January 8, Phoenix, AZ.

This collaborative study has led to additional funded research efforts by the National Science Foundation involving aerosol-lightning interactions over the Houston Metropolitan area (Experiment of Sea Breeze Convection, Aerosols, Precipitation and Environment; ESCAPE) and aerosol-cloud interactions in the Southern Hemisphere over the next three years. The current methodology will be improved upon to advance the body of knowledge regarding the impacts of aerosols on clouds, precipitation, and lightning in regions that are not well studied.
